content.webTitle: KSI v Logan Paul: boxing promoters look to cash in on YouTubers' rematch

fields.headline: KSI v Logan Paul: boxing promoters look to cash in on YouTubers' rematch
fields.bodyText: On 9 November, two boxers will face each other in the ring in a highly anticipated bout, broadcast live on pay-per-view TV and expected to generate millions of pounds. Nothing unusual about that, except the pugilists are not Tyson Fury and Deontay Wilder, or any of the sport’s big names, but two YouTube stars without a professional bout between them, fighting to settle a beef. The UK’s KSI – real name Olajide William Olatunji – and Logan Paul from the US first fought to a draw last year in a white collar event at Manchester Arena livestreamed on YouTube’s pay-per-view platform, billed as the biggest internet event in history. This time the stakes are higher as they have turned professional, which means no headguards and lighter gloves, increasing the chance of a knockout. The bout is being held at the Staples Center in Los Angeles and is promoted by one of the sport’s leading promoters, Eddie Hearn. In the UK, it will be shown on Sky Sports Box Office, a platform popularised by fighters such as Ricky Hatton, Naseem Hamed, Anthony Joshua and Floyd Mayweather. “It’s a joke,” said Rudy Genovese of the Paul v KSI fight. Genovese, who has been “boxing all my life”, was finishing off a sparring session at the Times amateur boxing club in north London, with some resistance exercises. “They will get hurt,” he said, before correcting himself: “But they won’t because they can’t fight.” Genovese, 51, a taxi driver, said his sons watched the first fight on YouTube. He had not really paid attention but saw enough to put him off. Tom Collins, a fellow cabbie who had earlier shared the ring with Genovese, was more positive. “I think it’s a good thing,” said the 40-year-old. “We want anything that will stop kids stabbing each other and [get them to go] training. If a fraction of the viewers get into boxing and take up the sport, that has to be a good thing.” In the shadow of a Muhammad Ali poster with the slogan “The pain you feel today is the strength you feel tomorrow,” Genovese remained unconvinced. “What they [the viewers] are seeing is not boxing,” he said. “Anyone can put gloves on but not everyone can box. They’re doing it without putting in the hard work and sweat.” No one in the gym was planning to stump up Sky’s £9.95fee, although Genovese conceded his sons would probably watch it. Questions were also asked about how the pair obtained professional licences. The British Boxing Board of Control (BBBoC) has no jurisdiction over the fight because it is in the US. Its rules usually demand experience in amateur boxing, with exceptions if there has been “proper and good tuition” under a professional trainer. Last year it refused the former England footballer Rio Ferdinand a licence. Including their last fight, KSI and Paul have three amateur fights between them (the Briton fought another YouTube star previously). KSI is being coached by Viddal Riley, a British boxer with three professional bouts to his name, while Paul’s trainer is the former world heavyweight title holder Shannon Briggs, who has been unable to obtain a licence to fight since failing a drugs test. KSI, 26, shot to fame through videos of him playing the videogame Fifa, while Paul, 24, made his name making shareable videos on the now-defunct Vine platform. Both internet stars have attracted controversy: Paul when posting a video showing the body of an apparent suicide victim, while KSI was accused of making sexist comments in his earlier videos. The disquiet among boxing fans has been exacerbated by the presence of two bonafide boxing world champions, the Briton Billie Joe Saunders and rising US star Devin Haney, on the undercard, although neither of them seem bothered. Before KSI and Paul fought last year, Hearn said the bout was embarrassing and that, as a boxing enthusiast, “I don’t think I could stand up there and sell, and be a part of that.” However, money talks. The protagonists each have about 20 million YouTube subscribers and more than 9bn views between them. Announcing the rematch, Hearn said witnessing the first fight he saw “a phenomenon, a sold-out arena, more than 1m pay-per-view buys but more importantly an energy of a new audience to the sport of boxing”. He has suggested the worldwide audience could be more than 50 million – although promoters are prone to exaggeration – so retaining the interest of a fraction would boost the sport. But despite seeing the positives, Collins was clear why Sky and Hearn were involved: “As soon as they see a pound note, they’re going to go after it.”
